elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0030" view="all">Self-assembly of Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(4-pyridylcarbonyl)-4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-diaminodiphenyl ether (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>), a dipyridyl-based ligand separated by phenyl amide spacer, afforded an interpenetrating Co(II) coordination polymer {[Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). X-ray analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that a unique combination of coordination and hydrogen bonds within a framework gives this material a spacious multi-channel structure. Moreover, the crystalline framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is virtually unchanged after removing the solvent molecules from the channels resulting in a nanoporous structure with estimated free volume of 31.4%.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Self-assembly of Co(NO3)2 and N,N '-bis(4-pyridylcarbonyl)-4,4'-diaminodiphenyl ether (L), a dipyridyl-based ligand separated by phenyl amide spacer, afforded an interpenetrating Co(II) coordination polymer {[CoL 2(NO3)2]⋅2(C2H5) 2 O⋅(CH3)2SO⋅H2O} n  (1). X-ray analysis of 1 shows that a unique combination of coordination and hydrogen bonds within a framework gives this material a spacious multi-channel structure. Moreover, the crystalline framework of 1 is virtually unchanged after removing the solvent molecules from the channels resulting in a nanoporous structure with estimated free volume of 31.4%.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0005" view="all">Many of coordination polymers with large cavities make these nanoporous materials potential candidates not only for the ion exchange , nonlinear optics , magnetism  and heterogeneous catalyst  but also for the guest absorption  and gas storage . Therefore, it is not surprising that a large amount of one- (1-D), two- (2-D) and three-dimensional (3-D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been constructed with simple linear spacing ligands such as 4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bipyridine (bpy) . More recently, the modification of bpy  to bifunctionalized forms has been drawing considerable attention as an alternative synthetic strategy for constructing high-dimensional coordination polymers with high porosity. The use of longer ligands, however, tends to lead the construction of frameworks with interpenetrating structure, which hinders the formation of the useful void space . In our efforts to investigate the self-assembly of nanoporous MOFs, a bpy-based ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(pyridylcarbonyl)-4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-diaminodiphenyl ether) separated by a phenyl amide spacer has attracted our attention in connection with the generation of new frameworks with enhanced cavity size. The amide spacer is introduced to form hydrogen bonds, which are very important for molecular recognition between receptors and substrates as well as construction of complicated supramolecular arrays . In fact, during the period of this research, Li et al.  reported the structure of M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-type (M=Zn and Cd) molecular squares, which we also obtained from the reaction of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the presence of PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion . As a result of continuing interest in this ligand, we have further carried out the assembly of MOFs based on <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, and found its chemistry is not parallel to those of previously known . Here, we report the synthesis and structural characterisation of a novel interpenetrating 3-D coordination polymer, {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) exhibiting multi-channels.<display>
<ce:figure id="figure0005">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</display>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Many of coordination polymers with large cavities make these nanoporous materials potential candidates not only for the ion exchange , nonlinear optics , magnetism  and heterogeneous catalyst  but also for the guest absorption  and gas storage . Therefore, it is not surprising that a large amount of one- (1-D), two- (2-D) and three-dimensional (3-D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been constructed with simple linear spacing ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) . More recently, the modification of bpy  to bifunctionalized forms has been drawing considerable attention as an alternative synthetic strategy for constructing high-dimensional coordination polymers with high porosity. The use of longer ligands, however, tends to lead the construction of frameworks with interpenetrating structure, which hinders the formation of the useful void space . In our efforts to investigate the self-assembly of nanoporous MOFs, a bpy-based ligand L(N,N '-bis(pyridylcarbonyl)-4,4'-diaminodiphenyl ether) separated by a phenyl amide spacer has attracted our attention in connection with the generation of new frameworks with enhanced cavity size. The amide spacer is introduced to form hydrogen bonds, which are very important for molecular recognition between receptors and substrates as well as construction of complicated supramolecular arrays . In fact, during the period of this research, Li et al.  reported the structure of M2 L 2-type (M=Zn and Cd) molecular squares, which we also obtained from the reaction of L and Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O in the presence of PF6 - ion . As a result of continuing interest in this ligand, we have further carried out the assembly of MOFs based on L, and found its chemistry is not parallel to those of previously known . Here, we report the synthesis and structural characterisation of a novel interpenetrating 3-D coordination polymer, {[Co2 L 2(NO3)2]⋅2(C2H5)2O⋅(CH3)2SO⋅H2O} n  (1) exhibiting multi-channels.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0010" view="all">The pink crystalline polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized from the reaction of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> in the presence of DMSO . The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a strong band at 1385 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> due to NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion in addition to other ligand peaks, which are slightly shifted in position from those of the free ligand and are of lower intensity. FAB mass spectrum of the product shows peaks at <ce:italic>m/z</ce:italic> 1125.3, 1062.0, 941.8 and 531.3 corresponding to [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-H<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The pink crystalline polymer 1 was synthesized from the reaction of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate and L in the presence of DMSO . The IR spectrum of 1 shows a strong band at 1385 cm-1 due to NO3 - ion in addition to other ligand peaks, which are slightly shifted in position from those of the free ligand and are of lower intensity. FAB mass spectrum of the product shows peaks at m/z 1125.3, 1062.0, 941.8 and 531.3 corresponding to [Co2 L 2(NO3)3]+, [Co2 L 2(NO3)2-H+]+, [CoL 2NO3]+ and [CoLNO3]+, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0015" view="all">The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with selected geometric parameters is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>
. The asymmetric unit contains two molecules of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, one cobalt and two nitrate ions. The potential twofold symmetry of the complex is broken by the different orientations of each carbonyl group as well as the trapped solvent molecules. The coordination geometry of the cobalt atom is distorted octahedral with four equatorial sites being occupied by four pyridyl <ce:italic>N</ce:italic> atoms from four different <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> in a propeller fashion and two-axial positions occupied by two monodentate nitrate ions. Four cobalt atoms are linked by four <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> forming a double-edged axe motif, whose shape becomes a puckered grid (). Four layers of the grid are repeatedly packed in a quadruple fashion (ABCD type) forming a 3-D framework (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>) and three adjacent grid layers are consecutively interpenetrated in parallel (⋯, ABC, BCD, CDA,⋯). The framework structure is also stabilized by hydrogen bonds between layers. The most fascinating feature is the formation of unique multi-channels with estimated free volume of 31.4%  and an effective size of ca. 9.5<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6.7 Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>). Each cavity is filled by four ethyl ether, two water, and two DMSO molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 1 with selected geometric parameters is shown in   . The asymmetric unit contains two molecules of L, one cobalt and two nitrate ions. The potential twofold symmetry of the complex is broken by the different orientations of each carbonyl group as well as the trapped solvent molecules. The coordination geometry of the cobalt atom is distorted octahedral with four equatorial sites being occupied by four pyridyl N atoms from four different L in a propeller fashion and two-axial positions occupied by two monodentate nitrate ions. Four cobalt atoms are linked by four L forming a double-edged axe motif, whose shape becomes a puckered grid (). Four layers of the grid are repeatedly packed in a quadruple fashion (ABCD type) forming a 3-D framework ( ) and three adjacent grid layers are consecutively interpenetrated in parallel (⋯, ABC, BCD, CDA,⋯). The framework structure is also stabilized by hydrogen bonds between layers. The most fascinating feature is the formation of unique multi-channels with estimated free volume of 31.4%  and an effective size of ca. 9.5×6.7 Å2 along the crystallographic a-axis ( ). Each cavity is filled by four ethyl ether, two water, and two DMSO molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0020" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis showed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> undergoes a gradual loss of 18.0% of total weight by 320 °C, corresponding to the loss of two ethyl ether and one DMSO molecules per formula unit (expected 18.2%). The results of powder X-ray diffraction patterns for crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> before and after removal of the guest molecules are consistent with that of the simulated pattern obtained from the single crystal data. This indicates that the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which allows the spacious multi-channels, is maintained throughout the process of removal of the guest molecules from the channels due to the interpenetration.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis showed that 1 undergoes a gradual loss of 18.0% of total weight by 320 °C, corresponding to the loss of two ethyl ether and one DMSO molecules per formula unit (expected 18.2%). The results of powder X-ray diffraction patterns for crystals of 1 before and after removal of the guest molecules are consistent with that of the simulated pattern obtained from the single crystal data. This indicates that the framework of 1, which allows the spacious multi-channels, is maintained throughout the process of removal of the guest molecules from the channels due to the interpenetration.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="simple-para0035" view="all">Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (3.5 mg, 0.012 mmol) dissolved in methanol was added to the solution of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> (10.0 mg, 0.024 mmol) in chloroform/methanol with a drop of DMSO. The vapor diffusion of ethyl ether into the solution afforded pink crystalline complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suitable for X-ray analysis (9.1 mg, 61%). It should be noted that the well-shaped crystals of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> lose solvent molecules and turn cloudy and cracked slowly under ambient temperature. Thus, the microanalysis data was obtained after the dry under vacuum. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>Co, [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O: C 56.42, H 3.75, N 13.71. Found: C 56.84, H 4.19, N 13.23%. Mp 204–205 °C (dec). IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3285m, 1684m, 1653m, 1604m, 1541m, 1499s, 1415m, 1385s (NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>), 1314m, 1254m, 1213m, 1168w, 1107w, 1016w, 834m, 695m. FAB mass (<ce:italic>m/z</ce:italic>): 1125.3 [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, 1062.0 [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–H]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, 941.8 [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, 531.3 [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (3.5 mg, 0.012 mmol) dissolved in methanol was added to the solution of L (10.0 mg, 0.024 mmol) in chloroform/methanol with a drop of DMSO. The vapor diffusion of ethyl ether into the solution afforded pink crystalline complex 1 suitable for X-ray analysis (9.1 mg, 61%). It should be noted that the well-shaped crystals of complex 1 lose solvent molecules and turn cloudy and cracked slowly under ambient temperature. Thus, the microanalysis data was obtained after the dry under vacuum. Anal. Calc. for C40H38O13N10Co, [CoL 2(NO3)2]⋅H2O: C 56.42, H 3.75, N 13.71. Found: C 56.84, H 4.19, N 13.23%. Mp 204-205 °C (dec). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3285m, 1684m, 1653m, 1604m, 1541m, 1499s, 1415m, 1385s (NO3 -), 1314m, 1254m, 1213m, 1168w, 1107w, 1016w, 834m, 695m. FAB mass (m/z): 1125.3 [Co2 L 2(NO3)3]+, 1062.0 [Co2 L 2(NO3)2-H]+, 941.8 [CoL 2NO3]+, 531.3 [CoLNO3]+

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="simple-para0040" view="all">Crystallographic data for C<ce:inf loc="post">58</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">63</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>S (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): FW = 1247.17, monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=13.408(2), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=28.992(4), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=18.414(3) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=124.041(2)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=5931.3(15) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>=1.397 g cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>=0.402 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <math altimg="si1.gif">F(0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0)=2608</math>, <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1.045, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=0.0856 and <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>=0.2333. All data were collected on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoK<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by full matrix least squares against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, for all data using SHELXTL software 
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data for C58H63CoN10O16S (1): FW = 1247.17, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a=13.408(2), b=28.992(4), c=18.414(3) Å, β=124.041(2)°, V=5931.3(15) Å3, Z=4, D c=1.397 g cm-3, μ=0.402 mm-1, F(000)=2608, S=1.045, R=0.0856 and wR=0.2333. All data were collected on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoKα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by full matrix least squares against F 2, for all data using SHELXTL software

<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–H]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, 941.8 [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, 531.3 [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>
</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (3.5 mg, 0.012 mmol) dissolved in methanol was added to the solution of L (10.0 mg, 0.024 mmol) in chloroform/methanol with a drop of DMSO. The vapor diffusion of ethyl ether into the solution afforded pink crystalline complex 1 suitable for X-ray analysis (9.1 mg, 61%). It should be noted that the well-shaped crystals of complex 1 lose solvent molecules and turn cloudy and cracked slowly under ambient temperature. Thus, the microanalysis data was obtained after the dry under vacuum. Anal. Calc. for C40H38O13N10Co, [CoL 2(NO3)2]⋅H2O: C 56.42, H 3.75, N 13.71. Found: C 56.84, H 4.19, N 13.23%. Mp 204-205 °C (dec). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3285m, 1684m, 1653m, 1604m, 1541m, 1499s, 1415m, 1385s (NO3 -), 1314m, 1254m, 1213m, 1168w, 1107w, 1016w, 834m, 695m. FAB mass (m/z): 1125.3 [Co2 L 2(NO3)3]+, 1062.0 [Co2 L 2(NO3)2-H]+, 941.8 [CoL 2NO3]+, 531.3 [CoLNO3]+

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0020" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis showed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> undergoes a gradual loss of 18.0% of total weight by 320 °C, corresponding to the loss of two ethyl ether and one DMSO molecules per formula unit (expected 18.2%). The results of powder X-ray diffraction patterns for crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> before and after removal of the guest molecules are consistent with that of the simulated pattern obtained from the single crystal data. This indicates that the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which allows the spacious multi-channels, is maintained throughout the process of removal of the guest molecules from the channels due to the interpenetration.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0040" view="all">Crystallographic data for C<ce:inf loc="post">58</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">63</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>S (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): FW = 1247.17, monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=13.408(2), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=28.992(4), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=18.414(3) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=124.041(2)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=5931.3(15) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>=1.397 g cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>=0.402 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <math altimg="si1.gif">F(0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0)=2608</math>, <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1.045, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=0.0856 and <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>=0.2333. All data were collected on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoK<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by full matrix least squares against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, for all data using SHELXTL software 
</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis showed that 1 undergoes a gradual loss of 18.0% of total weight by 320 °C, corresponding to the loss of two ethyl ether and one DMSO molecules per formula unit (expected 18.2%). The results of powder X-ray diffraction patterns for crystals of 1 before and after removal of the guest molecules are consistent with that of the simulated pattern obtained from the single crystal data. This indicates that the framework of 1, which allows the spacious multi-channels, is maintained throughout the process of removal of the guest molecules from the channels due to the interpenetration.

Crystallographic data for C58H63CoN10O16S (1): FW = 1247.17, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a=13.408(2), b=28.992(4), c=18.414(3) Å, β=124.041(2)°, V=5931.3(15) Å3, Z=4, D c=1.397 g cm-3, μ=0.402 mm-1, F(000)=2608, S=1.045, R=0.0856 and wR=0.2333. All data were collected on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoKα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by full matrix least squares against F 2, for all data using SHELXTL software

Symmetry codes: (a) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>+1/2, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−1/2, (b) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>+1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>−1/2, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+3/2.</ce:simple-para>

metadata.title: A three-dimensional interpenetrating framework with spacious multi-channels: synthesis and characterisation of a cobalt(II) coordination polymer based on an angular dipyridyl ligand incorporating an amide spacer
